title: 110_hr263
content: The Act titled "Cybersecurity Education Enhancement Act of 2007" establishes cybersecurity training programs and equipment under the Department of Homeland Security. The Secretary of Homeland Security, with the Assistant Secretary of Cybersecurity, will establish a program with the National Science Foundation to award grants to higher education institutions for cybersecurity professional development and associate degree programs, as well as equipment purchase. The Secretary will set program goals in consultation with the National Science Foundation Director. The program established under this section will be operated by the National Science Foundation, with the Director ensuring goals and criteria are met. Funding will be transferred to the NSF by the Secretary. Awards will be provided based on competitive, merit-reviewed peer review, with a focus on geographic diversity. The Director will prioritize geographic diversity and the inclusion of women and minorities in awarding funds. Preference will be given to consortium applications to benefit more students and professionals, especially those including institutions eligible for funds under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "institution of higher education" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. $3,700,000 is authorized for the Secretary for fiscal years 2008 and 2009. Establishment of the E-Security Fellows Program under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Secretary will establish a fellowship program for State, local, tribal, and private sector officials to participate in the National Cybersecurity Division. The program aims to familiarize participants with the Department's cybersecurity missions and capabilities, including enhancing government cybersecurity, developing partnerships, and improving information sharing on cyber threats. The E-Security Fellows Program aims to provide incident response planning, recovery coordination, training, and certification for individuals with cybersecurity responsibilities. Eligibility requires cybersecurity-related duties and eligibility for a national security clearance. The program consists of two 180-day iterations per year, ensuring that the number of fellows selected does not hinder Division activities. The E-Security Fellows Program requires employers to continue paying fellows' salaries and benefits during the fellowship. Fellows receive a stipend to cover living expenses.
